조승현, known by his handle “ainta,” is a highly accomplished competitive programmer from South Korea, recognized for his exceptional achievements in international programming competitions. Here is a detailed overview based on available information:

Background

  • Name: Sunghyeon Jo (조승현)
  • Location: Seoul, South Korea
  • Education: Associated with Georgia Institute of Technology and previously with Seoul National University (SNU), where he was part of the SNUPS (Seoul National University Programming Society) competitive programming club.
  • Online Presence: Active on platforms like Codeforces, AtCoder, Topcoder, and others, with the handle “ainta.”

Competitive Programming Achievements

  • Codeforces Profile:
    • Rating: 2870 (as of recent data), with a maximum rating of 3318, achieving the prestigious rank of Legendary Grandmaster.
    • Problems Solved: Over 2,774 problems solved on Codeforces, showcasing his extensive experience.
    • Contribution: Actively contributes to the community with blog entries, problem-setting, and contest participation.
  • International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI):
    • Represented South Korea in IOI 2014 and 2015.
    • Notably, he became the first Korean since 2003 to serve as a problem setter for IOI 2020, contributing a problem to Day 1, which was considered one of the most challenging. This highlights his deep understanding of algorithmic problem design.
  • ACM-ICPC:
    • Part of the SNU ACGTeam (with teammates 윤지학 and 최석환), which achieved remarkable success:
      • 2016 ACM-ICPC Daejeon Regional: 1st place, solving all 12 problems, a rare feat for an SNU team since 2008.
      • 2016 ACM-ICPC Asia Nha Trang Regional: 1st place, securing a spot in the World Finals.
      • Qualified for the ACM-ICPC World Finals in 2017, where his team competed among the top global teams.
    • Contributed to solving complex problems, such as “Conquer the World” at the 2018 ICPC World Finals, which no team fully solved. He later published a detailed solution explanation.
  • Other Competitions:
    • Samsung Collegiate Programming Contest: Won 3rd place in 2016, among other awards, as part of SNUPS, which collectively secured significant prize money.
    • Coder’s High 2013: As a middle school student, he won an iPad Mini as the youngest participant, earning the nickname “Korea’s Tourist” (referencing Gennady Korotkevich, a legendary programmer).
    • Participated in the Facebook Hacker Cup and other prestigious contests, consistently performing well.
  • AtCoder and Topcoder: Registered and active, with a strong track record in these platforms, further solidifying his versatility.

Contributions to the Community

  • Problem Setting:
    • Designed problems for high-profile contests, including IOI 2020 and various regional competitions like the “Thinking Programming Contest” (제5회 생각하는 프로그래밍 대회).
    • Served as a problem setter for the Samsung Software Membership contest and other events, collaborating with other top programmers like koosaga.
  • Educational Content:
    • Published detailed blog posts on advanced topics like Heavy-Light Decomposition, Segment Tree Beats, and Matroid Intersection, contributing to the competitive programming community’s knowledge base.
    • His explanations, such as the one for the ICPC 2018 problem “Conquer the World,” are valued for their clarity and depth.
  • Mentorship and Inspiration:
    • His approach to problem-solving, such as skipping difficult problems to maximize contest performance, has inspired others, as noted in a blog post by a fellow programmer.
    • Active in the SNUPS club, which has produced multiple top-tier programmers, fostering a collaborative learning environment.

Notable Characteristics

  • Early Start: Began competitive programming at a young age, gaining recognition as a middle school student in 2013 for his performance at Coder’s High.
  • Versatility: Excels in a wide range of algorithmic topics, including dynamic programming, data structures, optimization, and computational hardness, as evidenced by his blog posts and problem-solving record.
  • Community Impact: Known for both his competitive success and contributions to problem-setting and education, making him a respected figure in the global competitive programming scene.

Fun Fact

  • His nickname “Korea’s Tourist” reflects his prodigious talent, drawing comparisons to Gennady Korotkevich, the world’s top competitive programmer. This moniker emerged after his standout performance as a young competitor.
